awd_titl_txt: RAISE-TAQS: Entanglement and information in complex networks of qubits
awd_abstract_narration:
Quantum computers are now approaching a size that will soon perform tasks surpassing the power of today's fastest classical computers. To attain the full power of a quantum computer, qubits inside the quantum computer should be well connected with each other, so that information can be transferred, and entanglement can be generated between any two qubits as fast as possible. The qubit interactions will form a complex and time-varying network and their dynamics will be too complicated for classical computers to predict. This project will provide a key step in understanding quantum systems of a rapidly increasing level of complexity and find out how such complexity can be employed to massively speed up quantum computing over systems with sparse and simple qubit connections. The project will expand the fields of quantum information science and condensed matter physics into the territory of complexity science, via concrete ways to quantify complexity of quantum states. As the quantum information frontier is fostering a new technological revolution around the world, the project will train a new generation of undergraduate and graduate students with expertise in quantum technologies and develop a new 12-credit graduate certificate program in quantum engineering to accommodate the pressing need from industry professionals in obtaining quantum expertise.

The first half of this project aims to find out how high qubit connectivity can be used to speed up quantum information processing, focusing on mathematical quantum speed limits akin to Lieb-Robinson bounds, optimal entangling protocols for very small or very large number of qubits, and experimental demonstrations of entangling speed limit using solid-state qubits. The second half of this project will focus on states created by Hamiltonians with dense and complex interactions, quantifying their complexity and understanding their entanglement structure. Various network measures borrowed from complexity science will be employed to study the experimentally measurable quantum mutual information network and the recently developed quantum neural network, in order to bring new insight to quantum critical phenomena, entanglement area laws, and nonequilibrium many-body dynamics.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Our project aims to better understand the information propagation in a quantum many-body system with potentially nonlocal interactions, as well as the complexity of entangled quantum states generated by such a quantum system. Our team has successfully achieved these goals by identifying the speed limit of information propagation in a quantum system with strongly long-range interactions and applying tools from complexity science and machine learning to establish new paradigms for characterizing quantum many-body entangled states and the network formed by such states. The outcomes of the project will improve our fundamental understanding of long-range interacting quantum systems, guide the design of future quantum computers with non-local gates, and bridge the field of quantum information with the fields of complexity science and machine learning.

Intellectual Merit:

Our work addressed important open questions regarding how fast information can propagate and how entanglement can be generated in quantum systems with nonlocal interactions among particles. We have employed powerful tools in quantum optimal control theory to answer such open questions, leading to the best-known bounds on the speed of information propagation in strongly long-range interacting quantum systems and the fastest protocol for quantum state transfers on a fully-connected quantum computer. We have also designed and implemented experimental protocols to perform entangling quantum gates at or close to their theoretical speed limits.

In addition, we have expanded the fields of quantum information and condensed matter physics into the territory of complexity science and machine learning via new ways to quantify the complexity of quantum states. We have extended the study of complex network measures to complex-weighted networks relevant for describing quantum neural network states and studied the small-world effects of quantum networks. We have also applied state-of-the-art unsupervised machine learning methods to characterize the complexity of quantum many-body states and successfully identified a variety of quantum or dynamical phase transitions without any physical understanding of states.

As the quantum information frontier is fostering a new generation of technological revolution around the world, the outcomes of our project will push this frontier to a new level, bringing in potentially much faster quantum computing architectures and a deeper understanding of entangled quantum many-body states.

Broader Impact:

The interdisciplinary nature of our work that brings together several different fields, including quantum information, condensed matter physics, complexity science, and machine learning, shall have a broad impact on a wide range of scientific and engineering communities. Our work will set an example for scientists from diverse backgrounds to contribute to the fast-growing field of quantum science and technology, which is highly desired for growing the US quantum workforce. In particular, through this project, our team has trained a large number of undergraduate and graduate students for quantum research. These students have diverse backgrounds ranging from mathematics and physics to materials and computer science.

With the support from this project, we have also developed a quantum engineering graduate program at the Colorado School of Mines to accommodate the pressing need from a new generation of students as well as current industry professionals in obtaining expertise required for quantum technologies. We have also developed a number of core courses for this program, integrating many topics related to this project. We have seen a rapid increase in the number of students enrolled in this program due to our efforts, and it is now one of the largest quantum engineering graduate programs in the US.
